headline.main: Preserving the World's Reefs Through Photography

docs.abstract: A suitably squidlike camera that moves at a leisurely two and a half miles an hour will visually document the composition and health of the Great Barrier Reef along its full 1,500-mile span.
docs.snippet: A suitably squidlike camera that moves at a leisurely two and a half miles an hour will visually document the composition and health of the Great Barrier Reef along its full 1,500-mile span.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the issue of birth control coverage set to come to the Senate this week, Democratic leaders believe that voters will conclude that Republicans are overreaching on the issue.

headline.seo: Democrats Primed for Contraception Battle With Republicans
headline.main: Democrats See Benefits in Battle on Contraception Access
headline.print_headline: Democrats See Benefits in Battling Republicans on Contraception Access

docs.abstract: Senate Democratic leaders plan to hold a vote on controversial measure offered by Senator Roy Blunt, Republican of Missouri, that would in effect reduce insurance coverage of contraception by allowing religious institutions not to cover it in the health plans they offer employees; many Congressional Democrats hope that fight over bill will cut in their party's favor, believing that voters will conclude that Republicans are overreaching.
docs.snippet: With the issue of birth control coverage set to come to the Senate this week, Democratic leaders believe that voters will conclude that Republicans are overreaching on the issue.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and HELENE COOPER

docs.lead_paragraph: Is looking hard for things to be wrong a good way to promote health?

headline.seo: Overdiagnosis as a Flaw in Health Care
headline.main: If You Feel O.K., Maybe You Are O.K.
headline.print_headline: If You Feel O.K., Maybe You Are O.K.

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof H Gilbert Welch on rumblings within the medical profession suggesting that enthusiasm for early diagnosis may be waning; asserts while screening saves a few lives, it also drags many others into the system needlessly--needless appointments, tests, drugs and operations that make money for pharmaceutical companies, hospitals and doctors but do little more than cause anxiety for patients; holds that medicine must move back toward its original mission of helping sick patients, and letting the healthy be.
docs.snippet: Is looking hard for things to be wrong a good way to promote health?

docs.lead_paragraph: One percent of patients account for more than 25 percent of health care spending among the privately insured, according to a study.

headline.seo: At-Risk Patients Gain Attention of Health Insurers
headline.main: At-Risk Patients Gain Attention of Health Insurers

docs.abstract: Study finds one percent of patients account for more than 25 percent of health care spending among the privately insured; notes their medical bills average nearly $100,000 annually and they are typically people who suffer from chronic and increasingly common diseases like diabetes and high blood pressure.
docs.snippet: One percent of patients account for more than 25 percent of health care spending among the privately insured, according to a study.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the presidential primary on Tuesday, a defeat for Mitt Romney could send the nominating fight onto an unpredictable path and reset the Republican race.

headline.seo: For Doubts on Romney, Michigan Primary a Testing Ground
headline.main: Michigan a Testing Ground for Doubt on Romney
headline.print_headline: Michigan a Testing Ground for Doubt on Romney

docs.abstract: Political Memo; Republican presidential nominating contest remains uncertain into its third month; upcoming Michigan primary offers Rick Santorum his best chance yet to turn nagging questions about Mitt Romney into deep doubts about his candidacy; defeat for Romney could send the nominating fight onto an unpredictable path and reset the Republican race, but a Michigan victory could help cool misgivings in time for a challenging run of Super Tuesday contests that will allow another wave of voters to render judgment.
docs.snippet: In the presidential primary on Tuesday, a defeat for Mitt Romney could send the nominating fight onto an unpredictable path and reset the Republican race.

byline.contributor: Michael Barbaro contributed reporting from Rockford, Mich., and Katharine Q. Seelye from Lansing, Mich.
byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY and JIM RUTENBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: After decades of sloppy research, bad publicity, lawsuits and widespread fears of health hazards, the intrauterine device is making a major comeback in the United States. Although the IUD has long been the most popular reversible form of contraception worldwide, use of the device in this country, where oral contraceptives have always been far more popular, has lagged far behind that in other industrialized nations.

headline.main: Personal Health: Americans Get Reacquainted With IUDs

headline.main: Rising Health Costs Are a Top Financial Concern of the Affluent

docs.abstract: In a new survey from Merrill Lynch Global Wealth Management, wealthy Americans cited rising health care costs as their top financial concern.
